jeopardy_round: PHRASES IN THE KING JAMES BIBLE

(1, 1).clue: Genesis says "all the days of" this guy were 969 years, so if you're "as old as" him, you're really old

(3, 1).clue: These bakery pastries don't contain the "ursine" parts in their names; that would be too "grizzly"

(4, 1).clue: Deep envy, like I have for all of Johnny Gilbert's cool jackets

(5, 1).clue: In 1969 this 27-year-old seized power in a coup d'etat in Libya

(6, 1).clue: In the standard 3-class configuration, this Boeing jet seats 416

(1, 2).clue: Proverbs actually says "He that spareth" this "hateth his son"

(3, 2).clue: The Godiva candy called an "open" one of these bivalves is a praline "pearl" resting in a chocolate shell

(5, 2).clue: Around 950 B.C., a Libyan military officer seized this neighboring kingdom & ruled it as Pharaoh Sheshonk I

(6, 2).clue: It's the 2-word slang term for what is formally known as "time zone change syndrome"

(1, 3).clue: Cain's 5-word question to God in Genesis 4:9, when asked of Abel's whereabouts

(6, 3).clue: The first jet vs. jet air battle took place during this war

(1, 4).clue: Matthew 5:13 says that "ye are" this mineral phrase, meaning representative of the best of society

(3, 4).clue: No gastropods were harmed to make this sweet swirled roll (do the French call it a cinnamon escargot?)

(4, 4).clue: Seen here, this jumping mouselike rodent can jump faster than a human can run

(6, 4).clue: In the '60s, he began turning Swiss-built jet fighters into personal jets for the rich

(1, 5).clue: Not just for sick M.D.s, this 3-word proverb suggests Jesus should work miracles in his hometown as he did abroad

(3, 5).clue: The classic French cookie called a langue de chat looks like this kitty part--luckily, not an ingredient

(4, 5).clue: A bitter or warning rant, from the name of a Old Testament prophet

(5, 5).clue: Omar Mukhtar was the leader of a 20th century uprising against Libya's occupation by this European nation

(6, 5).clue: European nations joined forces to form this company whose widebody A300 was launched in 1974

(1, 1).clue: For messing up the words, among other mistakes, in 1894 this Italian tenor was dismissed from "Mignon"

(3, 1).clue: The Troubadour Theater Co.'s 2006 show about him was subtitled "The Artist Formerly Known as Prince of Denmark"

(4, 1).clue: This famous trick question is the title of C-SPAN's book on presidential gravesites

(5, 1).clue: JTF-2 is now this country's Elite CTU following the disbanding of its RCMP-SERT in 1993

(6, 1).clue: Hard physical work is made easier when you apply this type of "grease"

(1, 2).clue: Moving to Greece at age 13, she studied voice at the Royal Academy of Music in Athens

(5, 2).clue: This country's Special Forces include the Special Boat Service as well as the Special Air Service

(6, 2).clue: Lentigo senilis is a medical term for these brown signs of age on the skin

(1, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reads the clue from Steinway & Sons in New York.)  Steinway unveiled its 500,000th piano in a 1988 gala at Carnegie Hall featuring Steinway artists like this American pianist who has his own Fort Worth piano competition

(3, 3).clue: Aerosmith songs (& scantily clad cuties) enlivened "The Comedy of Aerosmith", a raunchy retelling of this play

(5, 3).clue: In 1994 this country formed a new special forces group, the Kommando Spezialkraefte

(6, 3).clue: You may "pay" someone this type of insincere respect, expressed with part of the mouth but not acted on

(5, 4).clue: A holdover from the Cold War, the Spetsnaz are some of this country's elite special forces
